reviewText: Katharine Hepburn plays the Madwoman who really isn't so mad. She has wisdom and insight into who is truly ruining the world and takes action in her own quirky way against the backdrop of Paris in 1969 with rioting students in the street, corporate big wigs plotting the destruction of Paris to extract oil, and greed meeting its final reward. A classic film and the basis of Jerry Herman's Broadway musical "Dear World" in the late 1970's. If you love film, you should check out this classic with such greats as Charles Boyer, Yul Brunner, Danny Kay, Donald Pleasance, and Richard Chamberlain. Unfortunately, it is only available as a Pan and Scan 4:3 version in Standard Definition even though it was produced and released as a wide screen color film. I hope they make this one available with a new rescanned version in full wide screen HD and with an improved soundtrack.
summary: Madwoman of Chaillot rings so true today, 45 years after it was released.
Title: N/A

reviewText: O.K., I admit it.  I'm the type who would watch Katherine Hepburn in literally ANY role and find something good about it.  There are plenty of flawed or mediocre works I have sat through just for her.  But the fact is that "Madwoman .." is a truly great film both as a comedy and a social critique.  A consortium of evil conspirators representing most of the world's repressive idelogies (Communism, religious fundamentalism, corpoate greed, rigid middle class conformism and military war-mongering)try to destroy the "decadent" city of Paris (symbol of liberty, beauty and humanism).  Kate, the city's defender, is a highly eccentric Countess who may or may not have some kind of semi-magical powers and who may or may not be immortal.  To make a long story short, the bad guys make her mad and end up buried alive (when asked if they will be missed she replies "Do you miss a cold when it is gone?"  Good answer!).  Don't mess with Kate!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is not your usual narrative. The vestiges of Jean Giraudoux's trifling and engagingly whimsical play can still be noticed in Edward Anhalt's interesting modernization of his work. Bryan Forbes ("King Rat") directed this unusual movie. The cast includes Katharine Hepburn (an extremely sane madwoman), Margaret Leighton, Edith Evans, Giulietta Masina, Charles Boyer, Yul Brynner, Donald Pleasence, Danny Kaye, John Gavin, Nanette Newman, Oscar Homolka, Claude Dauphin, Richard Chamberlain, Paul Henreid, and Fernand Gravet. There is some nice photography along the way. Not for all tastes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I encountered the works of Jean Giraudoux back in my freshman year of college.  His lyrical drama ONDINE was included among the selections in a French class I was taking, and THE MADWOMAN OF CHAILLOT (in English translation) was on the syllabus for a 20th century drama I had the same semester.  Being 18--and rather new to world literature--I guessed that Giraudoux must indeed be a major figure indeed and that I would, no doubt, be encountering the work of the great French dramatist again and again throughout my academic career--if not my whole life.Well, of course, I was wrong.  Not in my estimation of his greatness, certainly: I suspect that his reputation was well earned.  The two works did read made a strong impression at the time, but I as I soon learned, even in the groves of academe, one dabbles a bit here and then there.  There's no real definitive canon, just list after list of recommended titles (and authors) that at some point made their mark and deserve to be not-too-quickly forgotten.At the time, I was more of a movie buff than a theater fan, so I actually was aware that THE MADWOMAN OF CHAILLOT had been made into a film starring Katharine Hepburn a few  years before I ever got to college.  It wasn't a film that ever played anywhere near where I lived (in southern Maine), but I had read the reviews of it in the Boston papers.  And it seemed just counter-cultural enough to be of interest to a questioning 1960s era teenager.Well, decades after reading those reviews (AND the source play), I finally get to see the film on DVD.  And it really is a bit of period piece--although just what period is open to debate.  Giraudoux's play debuted in 1945 and its subtle allusions to Nazism and World War II would have been clear to contemporary audiences.  By the time the film was made in 1969,  the world was once again in a state of upheaval, and director Bryan Forbes and sreenwriter Edward Anhalt no doubt saw all kinds of interesting parallels.  I imagine the tempation to update the text in many ways-- (with references to nuclear war and to the violent student uprisings--was almost irresistible.  But as many a critic at the time suggested (I double-checked),  the fairy-tale quality of the original is all too often undercut by such time-specific references.The Madwoman herself--in her Victorian garb and demeanor--was probably just anachronistic enough in the mid-1940s.  Seeing her (and her three fellow "folles," prominading around amidst the long-haired and mini-skirted youths of "Swinging Paris" of 1969 is just bizarre, really.  The reach back to an 19th century sensibility doesn't make as much sense as it still might during the tumult of World War II era.  One can watch the film today and perhaps feel a tinge of nostalgia for 1969...or 1945...or (with enough stretch of the imagination, I suppose) for 1899.As a film, however, THE MADWOMAN OF CHAILLOT's bigger problem is likely just the classic old cinematic one of how to "open up" a stage play for the big screen.  The film could almost be recommended for its lovely exterior shots of Paris alone (a virtual cinematic necessity for ANY film that takes place in the "City of Lights," of course, but also an effective plot device in a film that has the possible destruction of a great city as its central theme).  Nevertheless, this "idea-play"  doesn't translate all that well into an "idea-movie."  It remains, as they say, "stagey."Yes, Katharine Hepburn is always worth watching--as is the stellar supporting cast, including Mararet Leighton, Dame Editih Evans, Yul Brynner and Danny Kaye.  The inclusion of Richard Chamberlain as a young student radical is one of the "up-to-date" bits that now seems a bit dated.  Or it may just be that he's a tad too earnest and (frankly) BLAND to come off as a young mid-60s firebrand.For a brief period in the late '60s and early '70s, Hollywood was making a clumsy attempt to accomodate vaguely countercultural ideals.  THE MADWOMAN OF CHAILLOT was certainly an earnest attempt at same.  I wouldn't dismiss the film as a mere period curio--I know people who love the film and find its message still quite meaningful--but for most contemporary viewers, it is a film that is very much of its era(s).
summary: It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad Woman of Chaillot

reviewText: Jean Giraudoux's play was a thinly veiled commentary on fascism according to many who have analyzed it.  But rather than write stereotypical Nazis as the villains, he chose to illustrate their cruelty in the form of industrialists who exploit anything and anyone for profit, even if it meant destroying beautiful, historical Paris to exploit suspected oil flowing far beneath the city's streets.  The movie moves forward on that theme and perhaps was not well received by some because they were not so willing to accept the idea of an amoral capitalist scoundrel conspiring with corrupt politicians and clergy to achieve profits at the expense of the society and world in which they live.Move forward into modern times and  when in the opening scene, the president (played by Yul Brenner) boasts about his rags-to-riches climb. He began as a petty thief, then a drug dealer, and finally a corporate boss. Only the president's corporations are mostly Ponzi schemes, as crooked as his earlier crimes. The essential thing, he says, isn't what a company does, but rather what it's called. What's required is a name that stirs the public imagination. Style over substance.  One looks at him and images of the Koch Bros, Ken Lay, Carl Icahn, Mitt Romney and other "venture" capitalists come immediately to mind.  The times sadly have caught up with the story.The Madwoman, or Countess, as she is also known, is the humanistic opposite of the industrialists. Older, maternal, warm, she's caught in a time warp.  Frozen in a time that no longer exists, reading the same newspaper for the same date every day, she treats all with warmth and maternal love. The people  around her love her for it.  Played by Katherine Hepburn she is the one who will act to destroy the evil she has discovered.There is not a lot of nuance here.  The street people, the hookers and bistro waitresses are good and gentle.  The wealthy and privileged are evil exploiters.  Yet listen to the speech of rag picker in their defense towards the end when he is their defense attorney.  The photography is wonderful, almost too wonderful.  There are many faces here you will recognize and their performances are well done.  The dialogue follows the play's script quite well and is poetic, often witty and enjoyable.  It you like your good and evil clear cut then you will enjoy this movie.  It's fun and entertaining and at times actually makes one pause and think.
summary: A play about fascism recast as a movie about the soulessness of human greed

reviewText: This was the most distressing film I can ever remember watching staring Katharine Hepburn. It was an all star cast but the subject matter was dreadful. She killed ALL the evil men in Paris who were plotting to destroy Chaillot, France (Paris) with oil wells. She schemed to lure a few men who were plotting to dig up Paris and put oil wells everywhere. It was the worst plot imaginable. When the dreadful deed was done, Katharine walked out of her manse in Paris and down the street and was gone, THE END! I don't know who thought this one up but they should have been tossed out of Hollywood or London or wherever they were writing this garbage. I don't recommend this film to anyone. One of the men she murdered was a preacher of the Gospel which to me was alarming in that it made a direct negative statement against God. Simply horrid! This is the only word of it.

reviewText: I have always loved the play and the subsequent musical adaptation by Jerry Herman with Angela Lansbury,  I often wishes that it would be revived on Broadway when she was still able to do it.  This film adaptation is interesting and clever but it strikes me as "period dated" with the look of the late 60s early 70s, (1969) films. However, the message is timeless for that time, before that time and now. It should be required viewing for the president, congress and senate. It shows that greed, corruption and lack of responsibility in people of power never dies and is there in every generation.  Let us just hope there is a Madwoman and friends to eventually thwart the baddies in each generation.
summary: A great story/play but not the best movie

reviewText: THE MADWOMAN OF CHAILLOT is one of Jean Giraudoux's masterpieces and anyone interested in this film would profit by reading Maurice Valency's superb adaptation of the original play (I understand Richard Wilbur has also done an excellent musical adaptation of the same work). I welcomed Bryan Forbes' film when it was released and still enjoy it today, but cannot feel totally happy with the final result as the original play is far richer, funnier, entertaining, subtle, and ultimately more poignant than Forbes was able to achieve here.  The entire cast is splendid and I especially admire Hepburn, Kaye, Boyer and Brynner for their respective performances.  I regret that Leighton and Evans, two of the greatest actresses of the English stage, have comparatively so little to do, and Masina is obviously miscast, although she is always a welcome presence in any film. The cinematography is extremely beautiful and does evoke the poetic universe of the play quite well. All in all, a flawed but important film. Bryan Forbes must be praised for having attempted to do what amounts to be a very difficult job: translate a theatrical fantasy into a film that succeeds as an indictment of a venal, corrupt, egotistical society. The play's message is still relevant, today more than ever, unfortunately.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Madwoman of Chaillot," based on a 1940s play by Jean Giraudoux, is one of those underappreciated treasures that rewards careful and repeated viewings.  Like another parable/allegorical fairytale from Sixties filmmaking, "King of Hearts"  (also set in France), it is an easy movie to dismiss as pretentious or longwinded.  But this is to judge on surface appearances or to hold the film to a standard that it does not seek to attain.  This work is a morality play, meant to instruct and illuminate; it is not a typical linear, real-world drama  -- although the interweaving of the real world of contemporary Paris with the fantasy world inhabited by the Countess (Katharine Hepburn, who is brilliant as usual) and her coterie of elegant female eccentrics gives the movie much of its surface charm.  Hepburn's Countess is not so much insane as preferring to live in an imaginary world of rosy nostalgia and  wishful thinking.  She and her friends fundamentally realize the difference between invention and fact but choose to generally ignore it.Let me be the first reviewer here to suggest that  the curious use of three aged women to represent the forces of justice at work in this dual world is a deliberate hearkening  to the Weird Sisters of "Macbeth", or the Furies of Greek tragedy, or even the Fates themselves.  Similarly,  the huddled poor of the Parisian streets and the menial laborers mostly have no names because they represent archetypes, perhaps -- a Greek chorus full of accusations for their tormentors.  They contrast  starkly with the smooth amorality of the movie's duplicitous villains -- an oil tycoon, a clergyman, a general, a politician,  a business consultant, and others  -- played to icy perfection and with just the right amount of absurd black humor by Pleasance, Brynner, Gavin, and their partners.  Richard Chamberlain, playing an idealistic activist,  adds a dose of romanticism when he leaves the world of the "faceless pimps" (in the damning words of Danny Kaye's relentless Ragpicker) and journeys for the love of Irma, a  poor waitress,  into the shadow world of the Countess of Chaillot -- although in doing so, he must destroy Hepburn's illusions forever, prompting her to take a terrible vengeance on the "greedy,  stupid, lost" men who have caused the world  to "not be happy."The climactic "trial" sequence, where the Ragpicker must play the devil's advocate on behalf of the collective monied classes, placed in the docket for crimes against humanity,  is a masterful performance by Kaye, playing  a non-clown role for once (who ever suspected he had it in him?).  With honeyed words, he  first seduces his "judges" into  falling for his deceits; then, when his lies are exposed for the pretense they are, he turns into a raging, bellowing monster of hatred, openly proclaiming his naked desire for money and power merely to  make war and destroy what's left of the earth.  Finally the mask has slipped; the court renders its verdict; and Hepburn's meting out of justice is as dreadful as any judgment of Nemesis.Which is all  very ponderous and heavy, but you can really take this film two ways -- whimsical  fantasy entertainment  or something much deeper and disturbing.  The  choice rests with the viewer, much as it lies with the characters in the movie to choose which path they wish to pursue.  "The Madwoman of Chaillot" may have been made over 30 years ago but the issues it raises and the attitudes it depicts are still very much with us today, and only someone as asleep and dreaming as the Countess wouldn't realize it.

reviewText: This has always been one of my favorite films, based on the very popular play by French dramatist Jean Giraudoux. It's an artistic film; allegorical, unconventional, full of metaphor, nuance and subtle ironic humor. It's a dreamlike, modern romantic fairy tale about true love, greed, corruption, stock manipulation, religious hypocrisy and imaginary friends. No digital FX, no guns, no car chases or fireball explosions (although there is a time bomb that goes off in the Seine river). Among the memorable scenes is the beautiful Paris street café, where Charles Boyer and Yul Brynner explain to the envious head of the KGB just how they manipulated the market to make millions that morning, and, together with the wicked Donald Pleasance, hatch a dastardly plot to get even richer by destroying Paris. And the famous trial scene, where the street people of Paris put rich people of the world on trial. The script is savvy, sparkling and ironic, and the cast is wonderful and perfectly suited to the material. The climax is compelling, and the ending is, well, shall we say, fanciful - but entirely satisfying. I've seen this movie a dozen times and, like the Fantasticks, The Princess Bride or the Wizard of Oz, it always seems timeless, fresh and fulfilling. This is an ideal movie for MBAs who need to see things a little differently. Plus, it's perfect for family viewing, and a good movie for young people, who instinctively understand the story better than many adults...
summary: Dreamlike modern fairy tale about greed, corruption & feather boas
